subject: English
note: Content vehicles for English Year 4. Seeded from v4 teacher feedback (Okonkwo). Each vehicle is a text study with reading, writing, and grammar integration.

vehicles.name: Adventure Narrative: The Iron Man
vehicles.description: Text study using Ted Hughes' 'The Iron Man' — reading for comprehension, inference, and prediction, then writing own adventure narrative with similar structure.
suggested_texts: The Iron Man by Ted Hughes
Stig of the Dump by Clive King
vehicles.writing_outcome: Write an adventure narrative (500-700 words) with clear problem-resolution structure, vivid description, and dialogue
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils identify the problem-resolution structure in The Iron Man? Can they make inferences about characters using evidence from the text? Can they write their own adventure narrative using fronted adverbials, expanded noun phrases, and correctly punctuated dialogue?
success_criteria: Identify the problem-resolution structure in the model text
Make inferences about characters supported by textual evidence
Write an adventure narrative with clear structure (opening, build-up, climax, resolution)
Use fronted adverbials, expanded noun phrases, and correctly punctuated dialogue

vehicles.name: Myths and Legends: Greek Myths
vehicles.description: Text study exploring Greek myths — reading for themes and conventions, comparing versions, then retelling a myth with own embellishments.
suggested_texts: Atticus the Storyteller by Lucy Coats
Who Let the Gods Out? by Maz Evans
vehicles.writing_outcome: Retell a Greek myth in own words (400-600 words) preserving key features and adding vivid description
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils identify common themes and conventions across different myths? Can they summarise main ideas across paragraphs? Can they retell a myth preserving key features while using conjunctions, pronouns for cohesion, and present perfect tense?
success_criteria: Identify common themes across at least 2 myths
Summarise the main events of a myth in correct sequence
Retell a myth with own embellishments while preserving key features
Use conjunctions, pronouns for cohesion, and present perfect tense accurately

vehicles.name: Persuasive Writing: Save Our Park
vehicles.description: Non-fiction text study focused on persuasive writing — reading persuasive texts, identifying techniques, then writing a persuasive letter to the council about a local issue.
vehicles.writing_outcome: Write a persuasive letter (300-500 words) using formal structure, rhetorical devices, and paragraphed arguments
grammar_focus: paragraphs to organise ideas around a theme
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils identify persuasive techniques in model texts? Can they plan and write a persuasive letter with paragraphed arguments? Can they use multi-clause sentences, fronted adverbials, and organisational devices for non-narrative writing?
success_criteria: Identify at least 3 persuasive techniques in model texts
Plan a persuasive letter with clear arguments organised in paragraphs
Write a formal persuasive letter with appropriate tone
Use multi-clause sentences and fronted adverbials effectively

vehicles.name: Poetry: Performance and Form
vehicles.description: Poetry study exploring different forms — haiku, limerick, free verse, narrative poetry. Reading aloud for performance, analysing language choices, writing own poems.
suggested_texts: The Works: Every Kind of Poem (ed. Paul Cookson)
A Great Big Cuddle by Michael Rosen
vehicles.writing_outcome: Write poems in at least 2 different forms and perform one to an audience
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils identify different poetry forms and their features? Can they discuss language choices and their effect on the reader? Can they write poems using appropriate form features and perform with expression?
success_criteria: Identify and describe at least 3 different poetry forms
Discuss how language choices create effects (imagery, figurative language)
Write poems in at least 2 different forms
Perform a poem to an audience with appropriate expression and intonation

vehicles.name: Information Text: Non-Chronological Report
vehicles.description: Non-fiction text study — reading and writing non-chronological reports. Cross-curricular link to Science or Geography topics. Focus on organisational devices and retrieval skills.
vehicles.writing_outcome: Write a non-chronological report (400-600 words) with subheadings, topic sentences, and integrated diagrams
grammar_focus: paragraphs to organise ideas around a theme
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils retrieve and record information from non-fiction texts? Can they identify how language, structure, and presentation contribute to meaning? Can they write a well-organised report with subheadings, topic sentences, and technical vocabulary?
success_criteria: Retrieve and record key information from non-fiction texts
Identify how subheadings, diagrams, and layout contribute to meaning
Write a non-chronological report with clear organisation
Use paragraphs, subheadings, and technical vocabulary appropriately

vehicles.name: Fairy Tales: Rewriting the Classics
vehicles.description: Text study comparing traditional fairy tales with modern retellings. Pupils explore themes, character archetypes, then write their own retelling with a twist.
suggested_texts: The True Story of the 3 Little Pigs by Jon Scieszka
vehicles.writing_outcome: Write a fairy tale retelling (500-700 words) with a twist on the traditional version
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils compare themes and conventions across traditional and modern fairy tales? Can they draw inferences about characters' motives? Can they write a retelling that subverts expectations while maintaining fairy tale conventions?
success_criteria: Compare themes and conventions in traditional vs modern fairy tales
Draw inferences about characters' motives with textual evidence
Generate and record ideas for a fairy tale retelling
Write a retelling with a twist using appropriate conventions and grammar

vehicles.name: Spelling and Vocabulary: Word Detective
vehicles.description: Systematic study of spelling patterns, prefixes, suffixes, and etymology. Pupils use dictionaries, investigate word families, and apply spelling rules in context.
vehicles.writing_outcome: Spelling log with word families, rules, and corrections applied in extended writing
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils apply prefix and suffix rules to spell unfamiliar words? Can they use a dictionary effectively to check spellings and meanings? Can they distinguish homophones in context? Can they spell words from the Y3-4 statutory list?
success_criteria: Apply prefix and suffix rules to spell words correctly
Use a dictionary to check spellings and find meanings
Distinguish common homophones (there/their/they're, etc.) in context
Spell the majority of the Y3-4 statutory word list correctly

vehicles.name: Discussion and Debate: Should Animals Be Kept in Zoos?
vehicles.description: Spoken language and writing study — structured discussion and debate on a moral question, leading to a balanced discussion text. Develops oracy alongside writing.
suggested_texts: Should There Be Zoos? by Tony Stead
vehicles.writing_outcome: Write a balanced discussion text (400-600 words) presenting both sides of the argument with a justified conclusion
grammar_focus: conjunctions, adverbs and prepositions for time and cause
paragraphs to organise ideas around a theme
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils participate in structured discussion, listening actively and responding to different viewpoints? Can they present both sides of an argument in writing? Can they write a justified conclusion using connectives for contrast?
success_criteria: Participate in discussion, listening and responding to different viewpoints
Articulate and justify own opinions with evidence
Write a balanced discussion text with for and against paragraphs
Write a justified conclusion using appropriate connectives
